Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: This afternoon, my daughter called, her voice bubbling with excitement. “Grandpa, Lily’s got the lead in her school play! She wants you to come over—she’s been practicing all week and wants to show the whole family.” My heart swelled with pride. I promised Lily I’d be there, and I know how much these moments mean to her. But as I hung up, my phone buzzed again—a reminder from the community center. I’m the only volunteer scheduled tonight, and I have the keys. There’s a line of people who count on me to open the doors and start the meal service. If I’m late, they’ll be left waiting in the cold. My family expects me to be present, to celebrate Lily’s big moment, but the people at the center expect me to be reliable, to show up when I say I will. I can feel the weight of both responsibilities pressing down, my mind racing as I try to figure out how to be in two places at once.
